channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: Government admits failures by Army and air traffic controllers in DCA crash
item.description: In a court filing, the government says “collective failures caused the mid-air collision that resulted in the senseless and tragic deaths of 67 individuals.”

item.title: What started as a 31-day stay became a ‘nightmare’ for a D.C. Airbnb host
item.description: A D.C. property owner said a woman stopped paying rent and claimed tenant rights to keep from being evicted.

item.title: Washington Nationals to hire 31-year-old Anirudh Kilambi as general manager
item.description: New president of baseball operations Paul Toboni is hiring Kilambi as his second-in-command in the organization’s front office. Kilambi arrives from the Philadelphia Phillies, where he spent four years as an assistant general manager overseeing their analytics department.

item.title: After Bondi Beach, it's a Hanukkah without light
item.description: For the crime of being Jewish, my people die and fight alone

item.title: FBI Deputy Director Dan Bongino announces he will step down next month
item.description: Bongino left a lucrative job as a conservative podcaster to serve as second-in-command at the FBI when Donald Trump became president. “Dan did a great job,” the president told reporters Wednesday. “I think he wants to go back to his show.”

item.title: I spoke to America’s ‘weirdest Democrat.’ And he’s on to something.
item.description: There’s no one in politics quite like the Democratic governor of Colorado, Jared Polis.

item.title: Senators freeze Coast Guard admiral’s promotion after the service enacted a new swastika and noose policy
item.description: The Democratic senators’ action follows a Washington Post report revealing that, despite Adm. Kevin Lunday’s forceful denunciation of such symbols and a separate directive he issued prohibiting them, the service allowed a policy to take effect that downgrades their definition from hate symbols to “potentially divisive.”

item.title: The Oscars will air on YouTube starting in 2029, departing ABC after more than half a century
item.description: ABC will continue to broadcast the Oscars through 2028, but YouTube has the global rights to air the awards ceremony until 2033. The awards show will be aired for free.

item.title: Senate passes Pentagon bill urging Hegseth to disclose evidence in deadly boat strike near Venezuela
item.description: A measure in the bill withholds 25 percent of Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth’s travel budget until he provides Congress with video of the Sept. 2 operation and other materials related to the Trump administration’s unprecedented campaign against Latin American narcotics traffickers. Eleven people were killed in that attack, including two men who survived an initial strike on their vessel.

item.title: Bowser to name Jeffery Carroll, D.C. police department’s second-in-command, new interim chief
item.description: Carroll, a 23-year veteran of the department, will serve as interim police chief after Chief Pamela A. Smith leaves at the end of the year, according to two law enforcement officials. Carroll led the D.C. police response to the Jan. 6 Capitol riot.

item.title: Appeals court hands Trump a win over D.C. National Guard deployment, allowing troops to remain in city while litigation continues
item.description: Judges wrote in a preliminary order that the National Guard can stay for now and that the Trump administration is likely to succeed in its appeal of a lower-court ruling.

item.title: Is it rude to ask restaurant staff to turn the music down?
item.description: Is it rude to ask restaurant staff to turn the music down?

item.title: In sign of GOP tensions, moderate House Republicans join Democrats to force vote on ACA subsidies, which are still likely to expire
item.description: Speaker Mike Johnson (R-Louisiana) had refused to allow a vote on extending the policy, fomenting the strongest rebellion among Republicans from swing districts to date. The subsidies are still virtually certain to expire because the Senate has already rejected the plan.

item.title: The inside story of Israel’s plot that killed 11 Iranian nuclear experts
item.description: A Washington Post-PBS Frontline investigation reveals new details about Israel’s Operation Narnia, the assassination campaign that targeted Iran’s nuclear scientists during the 12-day war.

item.title: An all-timer of a line in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Wednesday points.

item.title: ‘You see this news?’: What Charlie Kirk’s alleged killer told friends after the attack
item.description: A patchwork of social interactions and a trail of online posts provide a view into the life and beliefs of the suspect, Tyler Robinson.

item.title: Venezuela blockade. Susie Wiles. Nick Reiner. Bondi Beach. Charlie Kirk. Plastic chemicals. Younger brain. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Trump announces ‘complete blockade’ of sanctioned oil tankers to Venezuela
item.description: Such a blockade, which the president announced on Truth Social, would likely devastate Venezuela’s already struggling economy, which depends on overseas oil sales. He also declared the Venezuelan “regime” a foreign terrorist organization.

item.title: The unbearable sadness of the movie Rob Reiner made with his son about addiction
item.description: Reiner and his wife, Michele Singer Reiner, were found dead on Sunday. “Being Charlie,” a little-seen 2015 film that son Nick Reiner based on his own mental health struggles, is all the more heartbreaking in retrospect.

item.title: The statue of a Black teen who fought segregation supplants one of Gen. Robert E. Lee at the U.S. Capitol
item.description: Every state is represented by two statues in the halls of the Capitol building. In 2020, then-Virginia Gov. Ralph Northam (D) had requested removal of the state’s Lee statue and worked with a legislative commission to select Barbara Rose Johns as the replacement. Her statue joins George Washington’s to represent Virginia.

item.title: Federal judge suggests White House ballroom construction may continue but sets deadline to submit plans
item.description: Judge Richard Leon said Trump officials had two weeks to file plans for their controversial addition. Historic preservationists are demanding an immediate halt.

item.title: Director Rob Reiner’s son will be charged with two counts of first-degree murder
item.description: The charges against Nick Reiner, 32, were announced two days after his parents, Rob Reiner and Michele Singer Reiner, were found stabbed to death in their Los Angeles home.

item.title: Coast Guard enacts policy calling swastikas and nooses ‘potentially divisive,’ not hate symbols, despite top officer’s directive
item.description: The Washington Post was first to report on the U.S. Coast Guard’s plan to revise its workplace harassment policy. The Trump administration had sought to label the article as “false” — but within hours of its publication, the service’s acting commandant had issued a memo forcefully denouncing the symbols. It was not immediately clear Tuesday why publication of the new policy was not edited to align with the admiral’s directive.

item.title: She was MAGA’s favorite conspiracist. Then she dug into Charlie Kirk’s killing.
item.description: Candace Owens rose to prominence as a pro-Trump conspiracy theorist. Her latest claims have infuriated some of her former allies.

item.title: The architects of what? Find out in today’s On the Record.
item.description: Answer now to earn your Tuesday points.

item.title: ‘Kind of embarrassed’: In JD Vance’s hometown, I saw patience running thin
item.description: Middletown’s regard for its most famous son was more subdued than I’d expected.

item.title: Labor market lost 41,000 jobs over October and November; unemployment rate up
item.description: The unemployment rate ticked up to 4.6 percent in November, the highest since 2021, according to the Labor Department.

item.title: Gunman hunt. Bondi Beach. Rob Reiner. Military shake-up. Executive orders. Scientific meal plan. AI image challenge. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Robert J. Samuelson, a sharp-eyed and award-winning economics columnist at The Post, dies at 79
item.description: For more than 40 years, he helped readers make sense of economics and society. His plainspoken columns were informed by his classically conservative views.

item.title: Is a giant data center planned for your area? Check our map.
item.description: New data center projects are starting to transform landscapes and communities across the United States, sparking debates about what our energy systems and environment can sustain.

item.title: Pentagon plan calls for major power shifts at highest ranks of military, slashing number of generals who report to Hegseth
item.description: The effort, still subject to approval by President Donald Trump and Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, would include reducing in prominence three major headquarters — European Command, Central Command, and Africa Command — and putting them under a new International Command.

item.title: Authorities release new images of a person of interest in Brown University shooting along with $50,000 reward. Follow our coverage.
item.description: The images, captured about two hours before the shooting, show a person wearing dark clothes and a mask over the lower half of their face.

item.title: Commanders quarterback Jayden Daniels will be out for the rest of the season
item.description: The second-year star had missed Sunday’s win over the New York Giants after aggravating a left elbow injury a week earlier. When he was reevaluated Monday, team doctors still did not clear him for contact. The team then decided it would be best for Daniels to remain sidelined.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Dad thinks cancer survivor dyed hair purple for attention
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Dad thinks cancer survivor dyed hair purple for attention

item.title: Director Rob Reiner’s 32-year-old son arrested after the deaths of his parents, records show
item.description: Nick Reiner was booked into custody Monday morning on unspecified charges. Rob Reiner, whose career spanned decades in Hollywood, and photographer Michele Singer Reiner were found dead at their residence Sunday.

item.title: A growing chorus of Trump’s most faithful voters warns that his coalition is checking out. Will he listen?
item.description: President Donald Trump’s advisers say he is preparing to hold near-weekly rallies to spend more time with the base, but he has faced criticism from within MAGA in the meantime over cost-of-living issues, aligning himself too closely with billionaires, his handling of the Jeffrey Epstein case and more.

item.title: Make sure you fixate on today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Monday points.

item.title: Australia shooting. Brown University shooting. Rob Reiner dies. MAGA discontent. Trump library. Data centers. NFL. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Hollywood director Rob Reiner and his wife found dead
item.description: Reiner, the director behind beloved films like “When Harry Met Sally…” and “The Princess Bride,” and his wife, photographer Michele Singer Reiner, were found Sunday afternoon, according to officials. The deaths were confirmed in statements by Los Angeles Mayor Karen Bass and California Governor Gavin Newsom.

item.title: Authorities release person of interest detained after Brown University shooting
item.description: Rhode Island Attorney General Peter Neronha said late Sunday there was “some degree of evidence” that pointed to a 24-year-old Wisconsin man that authorities detained Sunday morning, adding that the "evidence now points in a different direction."

item.title: Hong Kong court convicts pro-democracy newspaper founder Jimmy Lai
item.description: The verdict exemplifies the reach of Hong Kong’s national security law and is being seen as further proof that Beijing has swept away any last remaining press freedoms and judicial independence in the once-freewheeling city.

item.title: What a top food safety expert won’t order for dinner
item.description: Bill Marler has litigated foodborne illnesses cases for decades. But even experts like him struggle to handle the risks.

item.title: Person of interest in Brown U. shooting is 24-year-old from Wisconsin, officials say
item.description: The person of interest authorities took into custody in connection with the shooting at Brown University is Benjamin Erickson, a 24-year-old originally from Wisconsin, two people briefed on the investigation told The Washington Post on the condition of anonymity. Erickson has not been named as a suspect or charged in connection with the Saturday attack.

item.title: 15 killed in Bondi Beach shooting carried out by father and son, Australian officials say
item.description: The death toll of Sunday’s shooting at a Hanukkah celebration at Australia’s Bondi Beach rose to 15, with at least 40 injured, Australian officials said. Authorities identified one of the gunmen as a 50-year-old man, who was also killed, and the suspected second shooter as his 24-year-old son, who was hospitalized.

item.title: Still need to finish this weekend’s On the Record? We’ve got you.
item.description: Play now to finish out your score for the week.

item.title: Are you living a good life? Take this quiz to find out.
item.description: Now is a good time to reflect on the life you’re leading — and what you want out of it.

item.title: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now
item.description: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now

item.title: It’s one of the driest countries in the world. The floods keep getting worse.
item.description: A Washington Post investigation found that in one of the planet’s most arid regions, extreme rain and floods have become frequent and deadly.

item.title: Police take person of interest into custody after Brown University shooting, Providence mayor says
item.description: Authorities said earlier that a gunman opened fire inside a campus engineering building on Saturday, killing two students and injuring nine others.

item.title: Police declare Bondi Beach shooting a terrorist incident targeting the Jewish community
item.description: The attack in Australia left 11 people dead and 28 others injured after two men opened fire Sunday evening during an event near the beach marking the first day of Hanukkah, authorities said.
